name: Dawid Kasprowicz
title: Dr. phil.
cv: Dr. Dawid Kasprowicz is a research assistant at the Chair for Theory of Science and Technology. From 2005 to 2012 he studied media studies and philosophy at Ruhr University Bochum and at the Université du Littoral Côte d’Opale in Dunkerque, France. He graduated with a Master’s thesis on Bernard Stiegler’s concept of psychopower. From 2013 to 2016, he was a PhD student at the " Media Cultures of Computer Simulation " Institute for Advanced Study at the Leuphana University Lüneburg where he also awarded a doctorate in April 2018. In his PhD thesis he develops a history of knowledge based on the concept of immersion. Since April 2021, he coordinates the fellow program at the Institute for Advanced Study on " Cultures of Research ", also at the RWTH Aachen University. In his teaching, he combines approaches from phenomenology with questions from philosophy of science and technology.
field: Philosophy and Media Studies of Computational Sciences/Head of CSS-Lab
researchInterests: Theory and history of embodiment; epistemology of human-robot collaborations; phenomenology; Philosophy of Science.

projects.name: At the limits of experience: Towards a phenomenological perspective in philosophy of science.
projects.description:
The concept of experience is mostly taken for granted in philosophy of science and rarely undergoes a deeper study. This project argues for the necessity to conceptualize “scientific experience” and to develop it into a wider framework to tackle current challenges in philosophy of science, especially in the context of computational sciences. To do so, a phenomenological approach will be chosen to locate experience in the scientific process of knowledge generation and to determine its epistemic function. This approach will also emphasize the relation between technically mediated experiences and cognitive acts of variating these experiences through imaginations and scientific practices.

A historical analysis of Husserl’s concept of scientific experience will lead to a new approach of man-machine-interactions in philosophy of science that takes insights from the phenomenology of technology and theories of enaction. This new approach argues that experience plays a crucial part in understanding the relation between the technological conditions of thinking and the ways in which research phenomena are accessed by an embodied, skillful scientific agent. In times of questions about the epistemic status of machine learning and computer simulations, we still have not touched upon the challenges concerning the intentionality and the skills of embodied agents who operate constantly with machines and instruments of knowledge production.
